bibl.title: Letter fragment from Henry Rose Carter to Wickliffe Rose, April 2, 1921

div1.p: Carter writes about the funding of yellow fever work in Peru.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Henry Rose Carter to Wickliffe Rose, April 2, 1921
div1.opener:
The Lonsdale, Apt. 206,
Washington, D. C.
April 2, 1921.
Dr. Wickliffe Rose, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
I am writing this letter to supplement our conversation of
last evening.

(1) The estimate, a copy of which I gave you, for the cost
of the work for the elimination of yellow fever in Peru is tentative
only. For instance, it does not include the Supervising Inspector
for the Province of Pacasmayo, whom I engaged in Panama for Hanson,
£p 80 per month and expenses--say 115-- nor the Physician--about
£p 150--whom he has stationed in this Province and that of Trujillo
to determine if other foci form to the South of the present infected
area. Both of these men are on duty.

(2) I know that Peruvian government is very short of funds,
and while orders have been given to the Custom Houses at Salaverry:
Pacasmayo: Eten and Paita to furnish funds to Hanson's order to the
amounts of the estimate submitted for each Department--their sum is
about £p 2400 monthly--it is a question whether they, the Custom
Houses--will do so contineously. From my experience it is fairly
certain that all of them will not always do so promptly.

(3) It then it be practicable, I would account it very ad-
visable to furnish Hanson with considerable funds (in lump) to sup-
